ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Heritrix requesting thousands of bad URLs from server.

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Heritrix requesting thousands of bad URLs from
 server.
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=UkjW5F5c9EelReeoz-gTpjixCl8sof05pz-tS0Lsqt1S
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

These look like legitimate URIs to me, rather than Javascript strings 
misintepreted as URIs.

It should be clear from the crawl.log's 'hopsPath' (the 'LEXR' string) 
and 'via' (referring URI) how and where these were discovered. 
(Alternatively, you can get this info from the view/edit frontier 
option, which appears for a paused crawl, to see queued URIs that have 
not yet failed-out into the crawl.log.)

If the server is refusing connections from your crawler, as the server 
might due to some sort of traffic-throttling policy, then yes, the 
crawler will put that queue into the 'long wait' (default 15 minutes) 
that is used when a network connection is impossible. Thus, that queue 
will make very slow progress.

However, all other queues should proceed as rapidly as ever, unless 
affected by similar blocks. If Heritrix appears to be crawling nothing 
over hours, then all queues with remaining URIs must be in a similar 
slow-failure, long-wait state.

So, I'm not sure what to consider the 'problem' to resolve. The crawler 
has discovered real URIs and requested them. The site has decided to 
stop accepting connections from your IP. If you configure the crawler to 
crawl more slowly, it might not trigger the connection-refusal-logic.

If the URIs were truly of interest, you could appeal to the webmaster to 
disable the block, or try crawling from another IP address.

If the URIs are really junk, and the crawler is just spinning trying to 
finish queues of defunct or otherwise connection-refusing sites, perhaps 
you just want to end the crawl.

HTH,

- Gordon @ IA

nfoscarini wrote:
> I'm having a problem with a crawl I'm running. At first I thought
> Heritrix had become stuck, but now I realize that it's been requesting
> bad URIs.
> 
> Heritrix has thousands of strange URLs queue like the one below.
> 
> http://www.gordiandata.com/search/redirect.php?f=http%3A%2F%2Fpagead2.googlesyndication.com%2Fpagead%2Ficlk%3Fsa%3Dl%26ai%3DB4HaEfrv_SNi1G5aU0AbGiaHAApr5z4wB-IXCnwnAjbcBgNfaAhAHGAcg-paRBigKOABQl8KFiv7_____AWD9oJmB6AOQAQKgAYaPqvcDsgEPZ29yZGlhbmRhdGEuY29tyAEB2gEXaHR0cDovL2dvcmRpYW5kYXRhLmNvbS-AAgGpAg3A1KsuyFU-yAKWyuMFqAMB6AO9AugDzAToA9wB6AMD9QNAAAAA%26num%3D7%26adurl%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Fbroadband.bigflix.com%2Fbigflicks%2Ffaces%2Fjsp%2Findex.jsp%26client%3Dca-dp-sedo-22_xml&tc=d5QVdYo48ffb8cf18136&
> LL
> http://www.gordiandata.com/parking.php4?&domain=gordiandata.com&sub=3&token=giJ6qI-ejzIKEwjf99qNgLyWAhUBvNQKHeJaDg4YACAAMIqRqAM4DVCKkagDUMu6iw9Q8d6KIQ
> 
> What's strange is that the domain gordiandata.com isn't a valid
> domain. It points to one of those reserved domain name pages, and not
> a real wesbite.
> 
> Something like the JS extractor created this URI.
> 
> My problem is that the server is returning 302 status for all the URI,
> but after requesting about a 100 bad URIs the server starts refusing
> connections. This appears to get Heritrix stuck, because it just sits
> there for hours not crawling.
> 
> What can I do to help resolve this problem?
> 
> Is it possible for Heritrix to detect this kind of problem and then
> remove the seed?
> 
>
